bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a first determination, for the next 3 calendar months for which disability assistance or hardship assistance is provided to or for the family unit, starting with the first calendar month

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: following the calendar month in which the minister made the determination, and
for which disability assistance or hardship assistance is provided to or for the family unit,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a second determination, for the next 6 calendar months for which disability assistance or hardship assistance is provided to or for the family unit, starting with the first calendar month

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: following the calendar month in which the minister made the determination, and
for which disability assistance or hardship assistance is provided to or for the family unit, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a third or subsequent determination, for the next 12 calendar months for which disability assistance or hardship assistance is provided to or for the family unit, starting with the first calendar month

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: following the calendar month in which the minister made the determination, and
for which disability assistance or hardship assistance is provided to or for the family unit.

bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 11 (1) (a) [reporting obligations] of the Act,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the report must be submitted by the 5th day of the calendar month following the calendar month in which one or more of the following occur:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a change that is listed in paragraph (b) (i) to (v);
a family unit receives earned income as set out in paragraph (b) (vi);

a family unit receives unearned income that is compensation paid under section 191 [temporary total disability] or 192 [temporary partial disability] of the Workers Compensation Act as set out in paragraph (b) (vii), and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the information required is all of the following, as requested in the monthly report form specified by the minister:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: change in the family unit's assets;
change in income received by the family unit and the source of that income;
change in the employment and educational circumstances of recipients in the family unit;
change in family unit membership or the marital status of a recipient;
any warrants as described in section 14.2 (1) of the Act;
the amount of earned income received by the family unit in the calendar month and the source of that income;

the amount of unearned income that is compensation paid under section 191 [temporary total disability] or 192 [temporary partial disability] of the Workers Compensation Act received by the family unit in the calendar month.

bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purpose of the re-establishment of eligibility under section 4.4 [re-establishment of eligibility for disability assistance], voluntary reports may be submitted on a monthly basis in respect of a family unit described in that section in the same manner and using the same form as in section 29.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of auditing eligibility for assistance or ensuring a recipient's continuing compliance with the Act and the regulations, the minister may do either or both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: require the recipient to attend in person on the date, and at the ministry office, specified by the minister;
require the recipient to complete a form specified by the minister for use under this section and deliver the form to a ministry office specified by the minister.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A recipient who is required under subsection (1) (b) to complete a form but who is not required to attend in person at a ministry office must deliver that form to the specified ministry office within 20 business days after being notified of the requirement to complete the form.
Delivery of the form under subsection (2) may be made by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: leaving it with an employee in the ministry office, or
mailing it to that office.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may declare a family unit to be ineligible for assistance if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a recipient in the family unit fails to attend in person at the ministry office when required to do so by the minister under subsection (1) (a), or
a recipient in the family unit fails to complete and deliver the form when required to do so by the minister under subsection (1) (b).

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 149/2015, Sch. s. 5.]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Consequences in relation to outstanding arrest warrants
bcl:section.bcl:text: Section 14.2 [consequences in relation to outstanding arrest warrants] of the Act does not apply to a family unit of an applicant or recipient for whom a warrant for arrest within the meaning of section 14.2 of the Act has been issued and who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is pregnant,
is in the end stage of a terminal illness, or
is under 18 years of age.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For a family unit to be eligible for hardship assistance, the family unit

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must be ineligible for disability assistance for one or more reasons set out in sections 37 to 41, and
must not be ineligible for disability assistance for any other reason.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A family unit that is eligible for hardship assistance must be provided with hardship assistance

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in accordance with Schedule D,
only for the calendar month that contains the disability assistance application date, and
subject to section 4 (2) of Schedule D, only from the date in that calendar month on which the minister determines that the family unit is eligible for hardship assistance.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A family unit to which hardship assistance has been provided for 3 consecutive calendar months because of the circumstances described in section 37, 39 or 41 is not eligible for hardship assistance under any of those sections for the 3 consecutive calendar months immediately following those 3 calendar months of receipt.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 141/2023, Sch. 2, s. 2 (b).]

bcl:section.bcl:text: Subject to this Part, the following sections apply in respect of hardship assistance:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: section 4 [application and applicant orientation requirements];
section 4.1 [application for income assistance — stage 1];
section 4.2 [application for income assistance — stage 2];
section 5 [applicant requirements];
section 6 [citizenship requirements];
section 6.1 [exemption from citizenship requirements];
section 7 [effect of applying for other sources of income];
section 8 [requirement to apply for CPP benefits];
section 9 [limits on income];
section 10 [asset limits].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applicants who do not meet requirement for social insurance number or proof of identity
bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide hardship assistance to a family unit that is not eligible for disability assistance because of the failure to provide a social insurance number or proof of identity required under section 4.1 (2) (a) (i) or 4.2 (3) (a) if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the minister considers that undue hardship will otherwise occur, and
the minister is satisfied that the applicant is making every effort to supply the social insurance number or proof of identity.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 69/2008, s. 2 (c).]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applicants who fail to provide sponsorship information
bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide hardship assistance to the family unit of an applicant described in section 6 (1) (a) or (b) [citizenship requirements] that is not eligible for disability assistance because of the failure to provide the information and verifications required under section 4.2 (3) (c) for the minister to determine whether unearned income described in paragraph (v) of the definition in section 1 (1) of "unearned income" is available to the family unit, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the minister considers that undue hardship will otherwise occur, and
the minister is satisfied that the applicant is making every effort to supply the information and verifications.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Family units that have excess income
bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide hardship assistance to a family unit that is not eligible for disability assistance because the income of the family unit exceeds the limit under section 9 [limits on income] if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the minister considers that undue hardship will otherwise occur,
the applicant provides the type of security specified by the minister for the repayment of the hardship assistance,
the family unit includes one or more dependent children, and
the income that causes the family unit to be ineligible for disability assistance could not, in the minister's opinion, reasonably be expected to be used to meet the family unit's basic needs.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applicant on strike or locked out
bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide hardship assistance to a family unit that is not eligible for disability assistance because an applicant is on strike or locked out if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the minister considers that undue hardship will otherwise occur,
the applicant provides the type of security specified by the minister for the repayment of the hardship assistance, and

the applicant satisfies the minister that the financial assistance that the applicant who is on strike or locked out is eligible for from the applicant's trade union, combined with the other resources of the family unit, is inadequate to meet the basic needs of the family unit.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Family units that have excess assets
bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide hardship assistance to a family unit that is not eligible for disability assistance because the assets of the family unit exceed the applicable limit under section 10 (2) [asset limits] if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the minister considers that undue hardship will otherwise occur,
the applicant provides the type of security specified by the minister for the repayment of the hardship assistance,
the applicant satisfies the minister that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the assets that caused the family unit to be ineligible are not immediately available to meet the family unit's basic needs, and
every effort has been made and continues to be made to sell the assets, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the family unit

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: includes one or more dependent children, or
includes only persons who have reached 65 years of age.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 141/2023, Sch. 2, s. 3.]
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 149/2015, Sch. s. 7.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Hardship assistance provided to a family unit under section 39 or 41 is not repayable if requiring the family unit to use the income or sell the assets, as applicable, that cause the family unit to be ineligible for disability assistance would put a person in the family unit at risk of domestic violence.

If hardship assistance is provided to a family unit, the family unit is not required to repay the amount of the hardship assistance, if any, that is calculated in accordance with section 5 (c.1) of Schedule D as it pertains to section 8 (2) (b) [people in special care] of Schedule A.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Supplements — Family Unit Eligible for Disability Assistance

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Supplement for purchase of co-op housing shares

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: To enable the family unit of a recipient of disability assistance to obtain residential accommodation, the minister may provide a lump sum to or for the family unit for the purchase of membership shares in a cooperative association.
A lump sum may be paid under subsection (1) only if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the family unit has received disability assistance or income assistance for at least the 3 previous calendar months, and
the recipient agrees in writing to repay the lump sum.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The amount of the lump sum under subsection (1) is limited to the smaller of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 50% of the cost of the membership shares.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (2):

bcl:definition.bcl:text: disability assistance includes a disability allowance under the Disability Benefits Program Act as it read immediately before its repeal;
income assistance includes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: income assistance under the BC Benefits (Income Assistance) Act as it read immediately before its repeal, and
a youth allowance under the BC Benefits (Youth Works) Act as it read immediately before its repeal.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 270/2019, App. 2, s. 9.]
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 196/2012, Sch. 2, s. 1.]
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 192/2006, s. 8.]
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 148/2011, s. (b).]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide a training initiative supplement to or for a family unit that is eligible for disability assistance of $50 each month towards the expenses of a recipient or a dependant in the family unit of participating in a training initiative program established under section 8 of the Act.

Only 6 monthly payments may be made under this section in respect of a recipient or dependant over any period of 36 consecutive months, beginning with the month the recipient first receives the supplement, unless more payments are authorized under subsection (3).

The minister may authorize up to 6 more monthly payments, if satisfied that the person participating in the training initiative program would, because of the nature of the person's disability, benefit from more participation.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 148/2011, s. (b).]

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 270/2019, App. 2, s. 9.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide a supplement to or for a family unit that is eligible for disability assistance and contributes $45 to the cost to provide an annual pass for the personal use of the spouse of a person with disabilities in the family unit if that spouse

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is 60 or more years of age,
receives the federal spouse's allowance or federal guaranteed income supplement, or
is 65 years of age or more and meets all the eligibility requirements for the federal guaranteed income supplement except the 10 year residency requirement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, annual pass means an annual pass to use a public passenger transportation system in a transit service area established under section 25 of the British Columbia Transit Act or in a transportation service region, as defined in the South Coast British Columbia Transportation Authority Act.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 270/2019, App. 2, s. 9.]
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 122/2019, App. 2, s. 2.]

bcl:division.bcl:text: Supplements — Family Unit Eligible for Disability Assistance or Hardship Assistance

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide any of the following supplements to or for a family unit that is eligible for disability assistance or hardship assistance to assist an applicant, a recipient or a dependent youth in the family unit to participate, in accordance with an employment plan, in an employment-related program:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: up to $100 for each calendar month to assist with transportation and attendance costs associated with participating in the employment-related program;
the costs of tuition, books and supplies required to participate in the employment-related program;
up to $200 for the cost of safety clothing required to participate in the employment-related program if the employment-related program is a workplace training or work experience program.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide a supplement to or for a family unit that is eligible for disability assistance or hardship assistance of up to $100 for each calendar month to assist an applicant, a recipient or a dependent youth in the family unit to participate, in accordance with an employment plan, in a volunteer incentive program as preparation for employment.

Only 6 monthly payments may be made under subsection (2) to or for a family unit in respect of an applicant, recipient or dependent youth over any period of 36 consecutive calendar months, beginning with the calendar month for which the family unit first received the supplement on account of the applicant, recipient or dependent youth, unless the minister authorizes up to 6 more monthly payments.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide a supplement of up to a maximum of $1 000 to or for a family unit that is eligible for disability assistance or hardship assistance if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a recipient in the family unit obtains confirmed employment that, in the opinion of the minister, will enable the family unit to become independent of disability assistance or hardship assistance,
in the opinion of the minister, the recipient requires transportation, clothing, tools or other employment-related items in order to commence the employment, and
there are no resources available to the family unit to cover the cost.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide a transportation supplement to or for a family unit that is eligible for disability assistance or hardship assistance for a calendar month, in respect of each recipient who is designated as a person with disabilities in the family unit, in one of the following forms:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in money, in the amount of $52;
in kind, in the form of a pass, deemed to have a value of $52 for the purposes of this regulation, for the personal use of the person with disabilities on a public passenger transportation system in

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a transit service area established under section 25 of the British Columbia Transit Act, or
a transportation service region as defined in the South Coast British Columbia Transportation Authority Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a recipient who is provided a supplement under either paragraph (a) or (b) of subsection (1) gives the minister notice that the recipient wishes to receive the other form of supplement provided under that subsection, the minister may provide that other form of supplement for a subsequent month.

An annual pass, as defined in section 51 (2) [spouse bus pass supplement], is deemed to be a supplement provided in kind under subsection (1) (b) of this section if the annual pass was provided to or for a recipient who is designated as a person with disabilities and who was previously provided the annual pass for personal use

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: as the spouse of a person with disabilities under section 51 (1), or
under section 66 (1) [bus pass supplement] of the Employment and Assistance Regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide a pre-natal shelter supplement of up to $195 per month for the duration of the pregnancy if the supplement is provided to a sole recipient without dependants who is a recipient of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: disability assistance under section 2 [monthly support allowance], 4 [monthly shelter allowance] or 6 [people receiving room and board] of Schedule A, or
hardship assistance under section 2 [maximum amounts of hardship assistance] or 5 (c) [calculation of maximum amounts] of Schedule D.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A sole recipient is eligible to receive the pre-natal shelter supplement while the sole recipient is pregnant, as confirmed in writing by a medical practitioner, nurse practitioner or midwife.
The minister may provide an annual winter supplement to or for a family unit that is eligible for disability assistance or hardship assistance.
The minister may specify

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount to be provided as a winter supplement, which may be different for different categories of family units, and
the time when the supplement is to be provided.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Clothing supplement for people in special care facilities

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide a supplement, for the purchase of necessary clothing, to a person with disabilities who is eligible for disability assistance or hardship assistance and receives accommodation and care in a special care facility if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: clothing is not provided in the facility,
there are no funds available from the recipient's comforts allowance to purchase the clothing, and
there are no resources available to the recipient's family unit to pay for the clothing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply if the special care facility is an alcohol or drug treatment centre or a special care facility operated by a service provider as defined in section 1 of the Community Living Authority Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Transportation to special care facilities supplement

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), the minister may provide a supplement to a recipient who is eligible for disability assistance or hardship assistance for transportation to a special care facility that is an alcohol or drug treatment centre.
A supplement may be provided under this section only

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the recipient receives the minister's approval before incurring the transportation costs,
if there are no resources available to the recipient's family unit to pay the transportation costs, and
for the least expensive appropriate mode of transportation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of this section, a reconsideration or appeal is determined when

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a decision of the minister or a decision of the tribunal has been made in the reconsideration or appeal, if the decision can be implemented without a further decision as to amount, or
if a decision of the tribunal requires a further decision of the minister as to amount, the decision of the minister as to amount has been made.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide a supplement to or for a family unit that is eligible for disability assistance or hardship assistance if a recipient in the family unit delivers a request for a reconsideration under section 71 [how a request to reconsider a decision is made] or submits an appeal form under section 84 [commencing an appeal] of the Employment and Assistance Regulation in respect of a decision that,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a family unit that is eligible for disability assistance, resulted in a discontinuation or reduction of disability assistance or a supplement, or
in the case of a family unit that is eligible for hardship assistance, resulted in a discontinuation or reduction of a supplement,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: but only if the recipient agrees in writing to repay the amount of the supplement provided under this section.
A supplement under this section may be provided for the shorter of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the period between the date that a request for reconsideration or an appeal form is delivered or submitted and the date that the reconsideration or appeal is determined, and
the period between the date that the disability assistance or supplement was reduced or discontinued and the date that the reconsideration or appeal is determined.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A supplement under this section is limited to the following amounts, as applicable:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the request for a reconsideration or the appeal form is in respect of a decision that resulted in a discontinuation of disability assistance or a supplement, the amount of the discontinued disability assistance or supplement;

if the request for a reconsideration or the appeal form is in respect of a decision that resulted in a reduction of disability assistance or a supplement, the amount by which the disability assistance or supplement was reduced.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the determination of a reconsideration or appeal that rescinded the decision being reconsidered or appealed did not require a further decision of the minister as to amount, the amount of a supplement provided under this section is not repayable and must be considered to have been paid in place of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the discontinued disability assistance or supplement, or
the amount by which the disability assistance or supplement was reduced.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the determination of a reconsideration or appeal that rescinded the decision being reconsidered or appealed required a further decision of the minister as to amount, the recipient must repay the difference between

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the total amount paid to the recipient under this section for the period under subsection (3), and
the total amount of any adjustment in favour of the recipient under the determination for the same period.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Supplements for moving, transportation and living costs

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: living cost means the cost of accommodation and meals;
moving cost means the cost of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: moving a family unit and the family unit's personal effects from one place to another, and
storing the family unit's personal effects while the family unit is moving if the minister is satisfied that storing the personal effects is necessary to preserve the personal effects;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: transportation cost means the cost of travelling from one place to another.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsections (3) and (4), the minister may provide a supplement to or for a family unit that is eligible for disability assistance or hardship assistance to assist with one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: moving costs required to move anywhere in Canada, if a recipient in the family unit is not working but has arranged confirmed employment that would significantly promote the financial independence of the family unit and the recipient is required to move to begin that employment;
moving costs required to move to another province or country, if the family unit is required to move to improve its living circumstances;

moving costs required to move anywhere in British Columbia because the family unit is being compelled to vacate the family unit's rented residential accommodation for any reason, including the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the accommodation is being sold;
the accommodation is being demolished;
the accommodation has been condemned;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: moving costs required to move anywhere in British Columbia if the family unit's shelter costs would be significantly reduced as a result of the move;
moving costs required to move anywhere in British Columbia to avoid an imminent threat to the physical safety of any person in the family unit;

transportation costs and living costs required to attend a hearing relating to a child protection proceeding under the Child, Family and Community Service Act, if a recipient is given notice of the hearing and is a party to the proceeding;
transportation costs, living costs, child care costs and fees resulting from

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the required attendance of a recipient in the family unit at a hearing, or
other requirements a recipient in the family unit must fulfil

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in connection with the exercise of a maintenance right assigned to the minister under section 17 [assignment of maintenance rights].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A family unit is eligible for a supplement under this section only if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there are no resources available to the family unit to cover the costs for which the supplement may be provided, and
subject to subsection (3.1), a recipient in the family unit receives the minister's approval before incurring those costs.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A supplement may be provided even if the family unit did not receive the minister's approval before incurring the costs if the minister is satisfied that exceptional circumstances exist.
A supplement may be provided under this section only to assist with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a supplement under subsection (2) (a) to (e), the least expensive appropriate moving costs, and
in the case of a supplement under subsection (2) (f) or (g), the least expensive appropriate transportation costs and the least expensive appropriate living costs.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Supplement to pay a security deposit

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, security deposit means a security deposit as defined in the Residential Tenancy Act, or an amount required by a cooperative association to be paid by a recipient to the cooperative association for the same or a similar purpose as a security deposit under the Residential Tenancy Act.
The minister may provide a security deposit to or for a family unit that is eligible for disability assistance or hardship assistance if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the security deposit is necessary to enable the family unit to rent residential accommodation,
a recipient in the family unit agrees in writing to repay the amount paid under this section, and
the security deposit does not exceed 50% of one month's rent for the residential accommodation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may recover the amount of a security deposit provided under subsection (2) in accordance with section 74 (2.1).
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 270/2019, App. 2, s. 11 (d).]
For the purposes of subsection (3), security deposit includes a security deposit provided on or after April 1, 2002 under the

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Disability Benefits Program Regulation, B.C. Reg. 79/97,
Income Assistance Regulation, B.C. Reg. 75/97,
Youth Works Regulation, B.C. Reg. 77/97, or
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 270/2019, App. 2, s. 11 (d).]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 193/2017, s. 5.]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Supplement to pay a utility security deposit

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, utility security deposit means an amount required by a utility provider of electricity or natural gas services to secure payment for the provision of residential electricity or natural gas services to a family unit.

The minister may provide a utility security deposit to or for a family unit that is eligible for disability assistance or hardship assistance, in an amount not to exceed the minimum amount required by the utility provider from a recipient, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the utility security deposit is necessary to enable the family unit to obtain or continue to obtain the services of the utility, and
a recipient in the family unit agrees in writing to repay the amount paid under this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may recover the amount of a utility security deposit provided under subsection (2) in accordance with section 74 (2.1).
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 193/2017, s. 6.]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Supplement to pay a pet damage deposit

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, pet damage deposit means a pet damage deposit as defined in the Residential Tenancy Act, or an amount required by a cooperative association to be paid by a recipient to the cooperative association for the same or a similar purpose as a pet damage deposit under the Residential Tenancy Act.
The minister may provide a pet damage deposit to or for a family unit that is eligible for disability assistance or hardship assistance if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the pet damage deposit is necessary to enable the family unit to rent residential accommodation,
a recipient in the family unit agrees in writing to repay the amount paid under this section, and
the pet damage deposit does not exceed 50% of one month's rent for the residential accommodation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may recover the amount of a pet damage deposit provided under subsection (2) in accordance with section 74 (2.1).
The minister may provide a crisis supplement to or for a family unit that is eligible for disability assistance or hardship assistance if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the family unit or a person in the family unit requires the supplement to meet an unexpected expense or obtain an item unexpectedly needed and is unable to meet the expense or obtain the item because there are no resources available to the family unit, and
the minister considers that failure to meet the expense or obtain the item will result in

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: imminent danger to the physical health of any person in the family unit, or
removal of a child under the Child, Family and Community Service Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A crisis supplement may be provided only for the calendar month in which the application or request for the supplement is made.
A crisis supplement may not be provided for the purpose of obtaining

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a supplement described in Schedule C, or
any other health care goods or services.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A crisis supplement provided for food, shelter or clothing is subject to the following limitations:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if for food, the maximum amount that may be provided in a calendar month is $50 for each person in the family unit;
if for shelter, the maximum amount that may be provided in a calendar month is the smaller of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the family unit's actual shelter cost, and
the sum of

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the maximum set out in section 2 of Schedule A, the maximum set out in section 4 of Schedule A and any supplements provided under section 54.3 [pre-natal shelter supplement] or Division 7 [Housing Stability Supplement] of Part 5 of this regulation, or
the maximum set out in Table 1 of Schedule D, the maximum set out in Table 2 of Schedule D and any supplements provided under section 54.3 or Division 7 of Part 5 of this regulation,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: as applicable, for a family unit that matches the family unit;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if for clothing, the maximum amount that may be provided in the 12 calendar month period preceding the date of application for the crisis supplement is $110 for each person in the family unit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 248/2018, App. 2, s. 2.]
Despite subsection (4) (b), a crisis supplement may be provided to or for a family unit for the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: fuel for heating;
fuel for cooking meals;
water;
hydro.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Advance for lost or stolen family bonus cheque

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide a supplement to or for a family unit that is eligible for disability assistance or hardship assistance as an advance for a lost or stolen family bonus cheque if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the minister is satisfied that an unendorsed child benefits cheque, the payee of which is a person in the family unit, has been lost or stolen,
the minister considers that the advance is immediately needed for basic needs of food, clothing or shelter,
the minister is satisfied that any steps necessary for replacing the cheque have been or will be taken, and
a recipient in the family unit does either or both of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: agrees in writing to repay the advance;
authorizes deduction of the amount of the advance from subsequent payments of assistance.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The amount that may be advanced under subsection (1) is all or part of the amount of the lost or stolen child benefits cheque that is attributed to family bonus.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 48/2010, Sch. 1, s. 2 (c).]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Advance for lost or stolen child benefits cheque — Canada child benefit

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide a supplement to or for a family unit that is eligible for disability assistance or hardship assistance as an advance for a lost or stolen child benefits cheque for the Canada child benefit in respect of a dependent child or dependent children, as the case may be, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the minister is satisfied that an unendorsed child benefits cheque for the Canada child benefit, the payee of which is a person in the family unit, has been lost or stolen,
the minister considers that the advance is immediately needed for basic needs of food, clothing or shelter,
the minister is satisfied that any steps necessary for replacing the cheque have been or will be taken, and
a recipient in the family unit does either or both of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: agrees in writing to repay the advance;
authorizes deduction of the amount of the advance from subsequent payments of assistance.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The amount that may be advanced under subsection (1) is the lesser of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount of the lost or stolen child benefits cheque that is attributed to the Canada child benefit, and
the BC child adjustment amount in respect of the dependent child or dependent children, as the case may be.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Supplement for delayed, suspended or cancelled family bonus

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, maximum national child benefit supplement, in relation to a family unit, means the amount the family unit would receive for a calendar month as the national child benefit supplement if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the family unit were entitled to receive the national child benefit supplement for the calendar month, and
the income of the family unit, for the purposes of calculating the national child benefit supplement, were zero.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide a supplement to or for a family unit that is eligible for disability assistance or hardship assistance if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: payment of the family bonus for a calendar month to a person in the family unit is delayed, suspended or cancelled under the Income Tax Act (Canada) or the Income Tax Act (British Columbia) for any reason other than that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the person refuses to apply for the family bonus,
the person refuses to provide information necessary to determine eligibility for the family bonus, or
the person refuses to accept the family bonus, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the minister considers that the supplement is immediately needed for basic needs of food, clothing or shelter.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The amount that may be provided for a calendar month as a supplement under subsection (2) is equal to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the maximum national child benefit supplement, minus
the family bonus, if any, received by the family unit for the preceding calendar month.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote:
Supplement for delayed, suspended or cancelled
Canada child benefit

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide a supplement to or for a family unit that is eligible for disability assistance or hardship assistance if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: payment of the Canada child benefit for a calendar month to a person in the family unit in respect of a dependent child is delayed, suspended or cancelled under the Income Tax Act (Canada) for any reason other than that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the person refuses to apply for the Canada child benefit,
the person refuses to provide information necessary to determine eligibility for the Canada child benefit, or
the person refuses to accept the Canada child benefit, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the minister considers that the supplement is immediately needed for basic needs of food, clothing or shelter.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The amount that may be provided for a calendar month as a supplement under subsection (1) is equal to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the BC child adjustment amount, minus
the Canada child benefit, if any,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: received by the family unit in respect of the dependent child or dependent children, as the case may be, for the preceding calendar month.
If the amount calculated under subsection (2) is less than zero, it is deemed to be zero for the purposes of this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Guide dog or service dog supplement
bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide a supplement of $95 for each calendar month to or for a family unit that is eligible for disability assistance or hardship assistance for the maintenance of a dog if the dog and a person in the family unit are a guide dog team, a service dog team or a retired guide or service dog team, as those terms are defined in section 1 of the Guide Dog and Service Dog Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide an annual school start-up supplement to or for a family unit that is eligible for disability assistance or hardship assistance if the family unit includes a person under 19 years of age who is attending school full time.
The minister may specify

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount to be provided as a school start-up supplement, which may be different for persons of different age groups, and
the time when the supplement is to be provided.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Supplement to obtain proof of identity
bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide a supplement to or for a family unit that is eligible for disability assistance or for hardship assistance to cover the cost of obtaining proof of the identity of a person in the family unit that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is required for the family unit to be eligible for disability assistance, or
in the minister's opinion, is required for a person in the family unit, or the family unit, to access services in British Columbia or for a similar purpose in British Columbia.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 21/2005, s. (b).]
In this Division:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: continuation date,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in relation to a person who is a main continued person under section 61.1 (1) [access to medical services only] as a result of having been part of a family unit on the date the family unit ceased to be eligible for disability assistance, means that date, and
in relation to a dependent continued person under section 61.1 (2) of a main continued person, means the continuation date of the main continued person;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: continued person means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a main continued person under section 61.1 (1), or
a dependent continued person under section 61.1 (2);

bcl:definition.bcl:text: maintenance, maintenance agreement and maintenance order have the same meanings as in section 16;
nutrition-related supplement means any of the following supplements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a supplement under section 66 [diet supplement];
a supplement under section 67 [nutritional supplement — monthly], other than a supplement for vitamins and minerals;
a supplement under section 67.001 [nutritional supplement — short-term];
a supplement under section 67.01 [tube feed nutritional supplement];
a supplement under section 2 (3) of Schedule C that is related to nutrition;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: qualifying federal benefit means a supplement under Part II or an allowance under Part III of the Old Age Security Act (Canada).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (4), a person is a main continued person if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person was

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: part of a family unit identified in subsection (3) on the date the family unit ceased to be eligible for disability assistance, and
a person with disabilities on that date,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person has not, since that date, been part of a family unit in receipt of income assistance, hardship assistance or disability assistance, and
in the case that the family unit referred to in paragraph (a) (i) was a family unit identified in subsection (3) (g), the agreement referred to in subsection (3) (g) is in force.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (6), a person is a dependent continued person if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person was a dependant of a main continued person under subsection (1) on the main continued person's continuation date and is currently a dependant of the main continued person, or
the person is a dependant of a person who is a main continued person under subsection (1) as a result of having been part of a family unit identified in subsection (3) (b), (c), (d), (e), (f) or (g).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A family unit is identified for the purposes of subsection (1) (a) if the family unit, while in receipt of disability assistance, ceases to be eligible for disability assistance

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on a date the family unit includes a person aged 65 or older,
as a result of a person in the family unit receiving an award of compensation under the Criminal Injury Compensation Act or an award of benefits under the Crime Victim Assistance Act,
as a result of a person in the family unit receiving a payment under the settlement agreement approved by the Supreme Court in Action No. S50808, Kelowna Registry,
as a result of a person in the family unit receiving employment income,
as a result of a person in the family unit receiving a pension or other payment under the Canada Pension Plan (Canada),
as a result of a person in the family unit receiving money or value that is maintenance under a maintenance order or a maintenance agreement or other agreement, or
as a result of a person in the family unit receiving financial assistance provided through an agreement under section 12.3 of the Child, Family and Community Service Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (5), a person's status as a main continued person under subsection (1) is suspended for a calendar month if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person fails to meet an applicable income test under subsection (7) in the calendar month and in each of the immediately preceding 12 calendar months, and
the person's continuation date is before those immediately preceding 12 calendar months.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (4) does not apply to a person who is a main continued person under subsection (1) as a result of having been part of a family unit described in subsection (3) (c) or (g).

A person's status as a dependent continued person under subsection (2) of a main continued person under subsection (1) is suspended if the main continued person's status is suspended under subsection (4).
For the purposes of subsection (4),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person who is a main continued person under subsection (1) as a result of having been part of a family unit identified in subsection (3) (a), (b), (d) or (f) meets the income test for a calendar month if,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in the case that the main continued person is aged 65 or older or the main continued person's family unit includes a person aged 65 or older, the main continued person or another person in the family unit is in receipt of a qualifying federal benefit, and

in the case that neither the main continued person nor another person in the main continued person's family unit is aged 65 or older, the adjusted net income of the main continued person does not exceed the amount set out in section 11 (3) of the Medical and Health Care Services Regulation, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person who is a main continued person under subsection (1) as a result of having been part of a family unit identified in subsection (3) (e) meets the income test for a calendar month if,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in the case that the main continued person is aged 65 or older or the main continued person's family unit includes a person aged 65 or older, the main continued person or another person in the family unit is in receipt of a qualifying federal benefit, and

in the case that neither the main continued person nor another person in the main continued person's family unit is aged 65 or older, the main continued person or another person in the family unit receives a pension or other payment under the Canada Pension Plan (Canada).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (7) (a) (ii),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: adjusted net income has the same meaning as in section 7.6 of the Medical and Health Care Services Regulation, and
a reference in section 7.6 of the Medical and Health Care Services Regulation to an "eligible person" is to be read as a reference to the main continued person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite this Division, a person is not eligible, as a main continued person under subsection (1), to receive a health supplement under this Division for the calendar month in which the person's continuation date occurs.

Despite this Division, a person is not eligible, as a dependent continued person under subsection (2) of a main continued person under subsection (1), to receive a health supplement under this Division for a calendar month in which the main continued person's continuation date occurs.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide any health supplement set out in section 2 [general health supplements] or 3 [medical equipment and devices] of Schedule C to or for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family unit in receipt of disability assistance,
a family unit in receipt of hardship assistance, if the health supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is under 19 years of age, or
a family unit, if the health supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is a continued person.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide any health supplement set out in section 2.1 [optical supplements] of Schedule C to or for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family unit in receipt of disability assistance,
a family unit in receipt of hardship assistance, or
a family unit, if the health supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is a continued person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), the minister may provide a health supplement under section 2.2 [eye examination supplements] of Schedule C to or for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family unit in receipt of disability assistance,
a family unit in receipt of hardship assistance, or
a family unit, if the health supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is a continued person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A health supplement under subsection (1) may only be provided to or for a person once in any 24 calendar month period.
A health supplement under subsection (1) may only be provided if payment for the service is not available under the Medicare Protection Act.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide any health supplement set out in section 4 [dental supplements] of Schedule C to or for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family unit in receipt of disability assistance,
a family unit in receipt of hardship assistance, if the health supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is under 19 years of age, or
a family unit, if the health supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is a continued person.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide a crown and bridgework supplement under section 4.1 of Schedule C to or for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family unit in receipt of disability assistance, if the supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is a person with disabilities, or
a family unit, if the supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is a continued person, and
was, on the person's continuation date, a person with disabilities.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), the minister may provide any health supplement set out in section 4.2 [denture supplements] of Schedule C to or for a family unit in receipt of hardship assistance.
A person is not eligible for a health supplement under subsection (1) unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person is not eligible for a supplement under section 63 [dental supplements], and
the person has had tooth extractions that were performed in the last 6 months because of pain and resulted in the person requiring a full upper denture, a full lower denture or both.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide any health supplement set out in section 5 [emergency dental supplements] of Schedule C to or for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family unit in receipt of disability assistance,
a family unit in receipt of hardship assistance, or
a family unit, if the health supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is a continued person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), the minister may provide orthodontic supplements to or for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family unit in receipt of disability assistance, if the orthodontic supplements are provided to or for a person in the family unit who is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: under 19 years of age, or
a person with disabilities, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family unit, if the orthodontic supplements are provided to or for a person in the family unit who

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is a continued person, and
meets any of the following criteria:

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the person is under 19 years of age;
the person was, on the person's continuation date, a person with disabilities.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For a person referred to in subsection (1) to be eligible for orthodontic supplements, the person's family unit must have no resources available to cover the cost of the orthodontic supplements and the person must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have severe skeletal dysplasia with jaw misalignment by 2 or more standard deviations, and
obtain prior authorization from the minister for the orthodontic supplements.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 145/2015, Sch. 2, s. 5 (b).]
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 313/2007, s. 2 (e).]

Subject to subsection (2), the minister may pay for a diet supplement in accordance with section 6 [diet supplements] of Schedule C that is provided to or for a family unit in receipt of disability assistance or hardship assistance, if the supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is described in section 6 (1) of Schedule C, and
is not described in section 8 (2) (b) [people in special care] of Schedule A.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person is not eligible to receive a supplement under subsection (1) unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person is not receiving another nutrition-related supplement, and
a medical practitioner, nurse practitioner or dietitian confirms in writing the need for the special diet.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide a nutritional supplement in accordance with section 7 [monthly nutritional supplement] of Schedule C to or for a family unit in receipt of disability assistance, if the supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is a person with disabilities, and
is not described in section 8 (2) (b) [people in special care] of Schedule A, unless the person is in an alcohol or drug treatment centre,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: if the minister is satisfied that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: based on the information contained in the form required under subsection (1.1), the requirements set out in subsection (1.1) (a) to (d) are met in respect of the person with disabilities,
the person is not receiving another nutrition-related supplement,
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 145/2015, Sch. 2, s. 7 (c).]
the person complies with any requirement of the minister under subsection (2), and
the person's family unit does not have any resources available to pay the cost of or to obtain the items for which the supplement may be provided.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In order for a person with disabilities to receive a nutritional supplement under this section, the minister must receive a request, in the form specified by the minister, completed by a medical practitioner, nurse practitioner or dietitian, in which the practitioner or dietitian has confirmed all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person with disabilities to whom the request relates is being treated by a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner for a chronic, progressive deterioration of health on account of a severe medical condition;
as a direct result of the chronic, progressive deterioration of health, the person displays two or more of the following symptoms:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: malnutrition;
underweight status;
significant weight loss;
significant muscle mass loss;
significant neurological degeneration;
significant deterioration of a vital organ;
moderate to severe immune suppression;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for the purpose of alleviating a symptom referred to in paragraph (b), the person requires one or more of the items set out in section 7 of Schedule C and specified in the request;
failure to obtain the items referred to in paragraph (c) will result in imminent danger to the person's life.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In order to determine or confirm the need or continuing need of a person for whom a supplement is provided under subsection (1), the minister may at any time require that the person obtain an opinion from a medical practitioner, nurse practitioner or dietitian other than the medical practitioner, nurse practitioner or dietitian who completed the form referred to in subsection (1.1).
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 145/2015, Sch. 2, s. 8.]

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide a nutritional supplement for up to 3 months to or for a family unit in receipt of disability assistance or hardship assistance, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is not receiving another nutrition-related supplement, and

a medical practitioner, nurse practitioner or dietitian confirms in writing that the person has an acute short-term need for caloric supplementation to a regular dietary intake to prevent critical weight loss while recovering from

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: surgery,
a severe injury,
a serious disease, or
side effects of medical treatment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, tube feed nutritional supplement means a liquid nutritional product that is fed to a person via a tube to the stomach or intestines of the person and the pumps, tubes, bags and other medical equipment or supplies that are required to feed the nutritional product to the person.
Subject to subsection (3), the minister may provide a tube feed nutritional supplement to or for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family unit in receipt of disability assistance or hardship assistance, if the supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is not described in section 8 (2) (b) [people in special care] of Schedule A, or
a family unit, if the supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is a continued person, and
was, on the person's continuation date, receiving the supplement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide a tube feed nutritional supplement under this section if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a medical practitioner, nurse practitioner or dietitian confirms in writing that the person's primary source of nutrition is through tube feeding,
the person is not receiving another nutrition-related supplement, and
there are no resources available to the person to pay for the tube feed nutritional supplement.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may provide the type of health supplement referred to in section 9 [infant formula] of Schedule C, in accordance with that section, to or for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family unit in receipt of disability assistance, if the health supplement is provided to or for a dependent child in the family unit,
a family unit in receipt of hardship assistance, if the health supplement is provided to or for a dependent child in the family unit, or
a family unit, if the health supplement is provided to or for a dependent child in the family who is a continued person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), the minister may provide a natal supplement in accordance with section 8 [natal supplement] of Schedule C to or for a family unit in receipt of disability assistance or hardship assistance, if the supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is not described in section 8 (2) (b) [people in special care] of Schedule A.
A family unit is not eligible to receive a supplement under subsection (1) unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person in the family unit is pregnant, as confirmed in writing by a medical practitioner, a nurse practitioner or a midwife, or
the family unit includes a dependent child who is 12 months of age or younger.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Health supplement for persons facing direct and imminent life threatening health need

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide to a family unit any health supplement set out in sections 2 (1) (a) and (f) [general health supplements] and 3 [medical equipment and devices] of Schedule C, if the health supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is otherwise not eligible for the health supplement under this regulation, and if the minister is satisfied that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person faces a direct and imminent life threatening need and there are no resources available to the person's family unit with which to meet that need,
the health supplement is necessary to meet that need,
the adjusted net income of any person in the family unit, other than a dependent child, does not exceed the amount set out in section 11 (3) of the Medical and Health Care Services Regulation, and
the requirements specified in the following provisions of Schedule C, as applicable, are met:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: paragraph (a) or (f) of section (2) (1);
sections 3 to 3.12, other than paragraph (a) of section 3 (1).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (1) (c),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: adjusted net income has the same meaning as in section 7.6 of the Medical and Health Care Services Regulation, and
a reference in section 7.6 of the Medical and Health Care Services Regulation to an "eligible person" is to be read as a reference to a person in the family unit, other than a dependent child.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Supplement for alcohol or drug treatment

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide a supplement for the cost of treatment, counselling or related services for an alcohol or drug problem that is provided to a person in a family unit who is a recipient of disability assistance or hardship assistance or a dependent child of a recipient of disability assistance or hardship assistance, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the minister considers that the recipient or dependent child needs the treatment, counselling or related services and there are no resources available to the family unit to cover the costs, and
the recipient or dependent child receives the minister's approval before incurring those costs.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The amount of the supplement under this section is limited to a total of not more than $500 for all treatment, counselling and related services provided to any one person over the previous 12 consecutive calendar months.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 145/2015, Sch. 2, s. 13.]
The minister may provide a health supplement set out in section 11 of Schedule C to or for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family unit in receipt of disability assistance,
a family unit in receipt of hardship assistance, if the health supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is under 19 years of age, or
a family unit, if the health supplement is provided to or for a person in the family unit who is a continued person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may require a recipient who is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: applying to participate in a self-employment program, or
participating in a self-employment program

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: to provide, for the acceptance of the minister and within the time specified by the minister, a business plan for the small business the recipient is operating or proposes to operate under the self-employment program.

If a recipient provides a business plan under subsection (1) that is not acceptable to the minister, the minister may return the business plan to the recipient with directions and the recipient may resubmit the business plan within the time specified by the minister for that purpose.
If

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a recipient fails to provide a business plan in the time specified under subsection (1) or (2), as applicable, or
a recipient provides a business plan that is not acceptable to the minister, the recipient is not or ceases to be eligible to participate in the self-employment program.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If a recipient who is participating in a self-employment program is operating a small business under the program, the recipient must, in addition to any report required under section 29, provide a monthly report to the minister in the form and at the time specified by the minister, setting out, for the period covered by the report, as required by the form, the business activities, earnings, expenses, assets and liabilities of the small business the recipient is operating.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Consequences in Relation to Outstanding Arrest Warrants

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Supplement to prevent undue hardship while dealing with outstanding arrest warrant

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide a supplement to or for a family unit of an applicant or recipient for whom a warrant for arrest within the meaning of section 14.2 [consequences in relation to outstanding arrest warrants] of the Act has been issued for the purposes of section 14.2 (2) (a) of the Act, if the minister considers that undue hardship will otherwise occur.
A supplement under this section may be provided only for the calendar month in which the supplement is requested.
A supplement under this section may be provided for only 3 consecutive calendar months unless the minister authorizes up to 3 more consecutive monthly payments.
Despite any other section of this regulation, the maximum amount of a supplement provided under subsection (1) is the difference between

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the maximum amount of disability assistance determined under Schedule A for the calendar month for a family unit that matches the family unit in size but does not include a person for whom a warrant for arrest within the meaning of section 14.2 of the Act has been issued, and
the amount of disability assistance provided for the calendar month to the family unit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A recipient of a supplement must agree in writing to repay the amount paid under this section.
In this section, living cost means the cost of accommodation and meals required for a person or family unit to return to the jurisdiction that issued the warrant.
The minister may provide a supplement to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an applicant or recipient for whom a warrant for arrest within the meaning of section 14.2 [consequences in relation to outstanding arrest warrants] of the Act has been issued, for the purposes of section 14.2 (2) (b) (i) of the Act, or
the family unit of an applicant or recipient for whom a warrant of arrest within the meaning of section 14.2 of the Act has been issued for the purposes of section 14.2 (2) (b) (ii) of the Act,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there are no resources available to the family unit to cover the cost of returning to the jurisdiction that issued the warrant, and
the minister is satisfied that the supplement will be used by the person or family unit to return to the jurisdiction that issued the warrant to deal with the warrant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite any other section of this regulation, a supplement provided under subsection (2) is limited to an amount not to exceed the cost of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the least expensive appropriate mode of transportation, and
the least expensive appropriate living cost

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: to return the person or family unit to the jurisdiction that issued the warrant.
A recipient of a supplement must agree in writing to repay the amount paid under this section.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Division:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: detained person means a person described in section 14 [effect of being in prison or other lawful place of confinement];
person in special care means a person who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: receives accommodation and care in a special care facility or a private hospital, other than a special care facility operated by a service provider as defined in section 1 of the Community Living Authority Act, or
is admitted to a hospital because the person requires extended care;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: removed child, in relation to a family unit, means a dependent child who is living away from the ordinary residence of the family unit under

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an interim order or temporary custody order under the Child, Family and Community Service Act, or
an agreement under section 6, 7 or 8 of that Act;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: specified person means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a removed child,
a detained person, or
a person in special care.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide a housing stability supplement to or for a family unit that is eligible for disability assistance or hardship assistance on account of one or more of the following persons:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a deceased person who was part of the family unit, if the family unit was eligible for disability assistance, income assistance or hardship assistance for the calendar month of the death and all subsequent calendar months;

a specified person who is part of the family unit, if the family unit included the specified person in, and was eligible for disability assistance, income assistance or hardship assistance for, the calendar month in which the person became a specified person and all subsequent calendar months.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The amount that may be provided as a supplement under this section for a calendar month on account of persons described in subsection (1) (a) or (b) is the lesser of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the greater of zero and the difference between

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the actual shelter costs of the family unit for the month, and
the shelter allowance calculated under Schedule A or Schedule D, as applicable, for the family unit for the month, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the difference between

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the amount that would be determined under Schedule A or Schedule D, as applicable, for the family unit for the month if the persons were not deceased persons or specified persons, and
the amount determined under Schedule A or Schedule D, as applicable, excluding an amount described in section 8 (2) (b) (i) [people in special care] of Schedule A, for the family unit for the month.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Housing stability supplement — family unit with only detained persons

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may provide a housing stability supplement to or for a family unit that includes only one or more detained persons if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the family unit included the persons in the calendar months in which the persons became detained persons and all subsequent calendar months, and

the family unit was, or would have been but for the detentions, eligible for disability assistance, income assistance or hardship assistance for the calendar months in which the persons became detained persons and all subsequent calendar months.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The amount that may be provided as a supplement under this section for a calendar month on account of the detained persons is the lesser of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the actual shelter costs of the family unit for the month, and
the disability assistance or hardship assistance, as applicable, for which the family unit would be eligible for the month if the persons were not detained persons.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), a supplement under this Division may be provided for only 3 consecutive calendar months unless the minister authorizes up to 3 more consecutive monthly payments.
The time limit in subsection (1) does not apply in relation to a supplement that is provided on account of a removed child.
The time limit in subsection (1) is restarted in relation to a supplement that is provided on account of a person if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person dies while a specified person, or
the person

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: was a detained person and becomes a person in care,
was a person in care and becomes a detained person,
was a person in care in a hospital or private hospital and becomes a person in care in a special care facility, or
was a person in care in a special care facility and becomes a person in care in a hospital or private hospital.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: How a request to reconsider a decision is made

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who wishes the minister to reconsider a decision referred to in section 16 (1) [reconsideration and appeal rights] of the Act must deliver a request for reconsideration in the form specified by the minister to the ministry office where the person is applying for or receiving assistance.
A request under subsection (1) must be delivered within 20 business days after the date the person is notified of the decision referred to in section 16 (1) of the Act and may be delivered by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: leaving it with an employee in the ministry office, or
being received through the mail at that office.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister must reconsider a decision referred to in section 16 (1) of the Act, and mail a written determination on the reconsideration to the person who delivered the request under section 71 (1) [how a request to reconsider a decision is made],

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within 10 business days after receiving the request, or
if the minister considers it necessary in the circumstances and the person consents, within 20 business days after receiving the request.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Decisions that may not be appealed

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following categories of supplements may not be appealed to the tribunal:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 313/2007, s. 2 (f).]
reconsideration and appeal supplements under section 54.7;
supplements related to employment plans under section 54;
access to a program established or funded under the Act;
confirmed job supplements under section 54.1;
supplements under section 70.3;
supplements under section 70.4.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A decision to refuse to provide disability assistance, hardship assistance or a supplement is not appealable to the tribunal if the person who would bring the appeal is awaiting a reconsideration of the minister or the decision of a panel on an earlier request for reconsideration the person made, or an appeal the person brought, respecting the same matter.
In this section and sections 74.1 and 74.2:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Act offence means an offence under the Act or the Employment and Assistance Act;

benefit month, in relation to a family unit, means a calendar month for which the family unit is eligible for an amount of assistance under the Act or the Employment and Assistance Act, and, for certainty, consecutive benefit months need not be consecutive calendar months;
criminal code offence means an offence under the Criminal Code in relation to obtaining money, under the Act or the Employment and Assistance Act, by fraud or false or misleading representation;
deposit debt means a supplement provided to or for a family unit on a repayable basis under

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: section 56 (2) [supplement to pay a security deposit], 56.1 (2) [supplement to pay a utility security deposit] or 56.2 (2) [supplement to pay a pet damage deposit], or

section 58 (2) [supplement to pay a security deposit], 58.1 (2) [supplement to pay a utility security deposit] or 58.2 (2) [supplement to pay a pet damage deposit] of the Employment and Assistance Regulation;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: offence overpayment means an overpayment that is or was provided to or for a family unit as a result of a criminal code offence or Act offence for which a recipient in the family unit has been or is convicted, whether the conviction occurred before or after the date this section came into force;
overpayment means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an overpayment described in section 18 (1) [overpayments] of the Act or section 27 (1) [overpayments] of the Employment and Assistance Act,

an amount of assistance provided under the Act to or for a family unit on a repayable basis, other than a supplement under section 56 (2) [supplement to pay a security deposit], 56.1 (2) [supplement to pay a utility security deposit] or 56.2 (2) [supplement to pay a pet damage deposit] of this regulation,

an amount of assistance provided under the Employment and Assistance Act to or for a family unit on a repayable basis, other than a supplement under section 58 (2) [supplement to pay a security deposit], 58.1 (2) [supplement to pay a utility security deposit] or 58.2 (2) [supplement to pay a pet damage deposit] of the Employment and Assistance Regulation, or
a debt referred to in section 33 [indebtedness under former Act] of the Act or section 42 [indebtedness under former Act] of the Employment and Assistance Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to sections 74.1 and 74.2, for a family unit that includes one or more recipients who are liable for one or more overpayments, the amount that is to be deducted for the purposes of section 19 (1) (b) [liability for and recovery of debts under Act] of the Act is $10 each benefit month, regardless of the number of overpayments.

Subject to sections 74.1 and 74.2, for a family unit that includes one or more recipients who are liable for one or more deposit debts, the amount that is to be deducted for the purposes of section 19 (1) (b) of the Act is $20 each benefit month, regardless of the number of deposit debts.

Subject to sections 74.1 and 74.2, for a family unit that includes one or more recipients who are liable for one or more offence overpayments, the amount that is to be deducted for the purposes of section 19 (1) (b) of the Act for a benefit month is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: $100 for each recipient in the family unit whose conviction for a criminal code offence or Act offence resulted in an offence overpayment, or
if the balance of the amounts of offence overpayments in relation to a recipient in the family unit is less than $100, that balance in relation to that recipient.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A deduction under subsection (3) in relation to an offence overpayment provided to or for a family unit as a result of a criminal code offence

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: begins for the first benefit month following the date the recipient is convicted of the criminal code offence, and
continues for each consecutive benefit month until the amount of the offence overpayment is recovered.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A deduction under subsection (3) in relation to an offence overpayment provided to or for a family unit as a result of an Act offence

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: begins for the first benefit month following the date the recipient is convicted of the Act offence, and
continues, unless the amount of the offence overpayment is earlier recovered,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: after a first conviction of the recipient for an Act offence, until the deduction has been made for 12 consecutive benefit months in relation to the first offence overpayment,
after a second conviction of that recipient for an Act offence, until the deduction has been made for 24 consecutive benefit months in relation to the second offence overpayment, and
after a third or subsequent conviction of that recipient for an Act offence, until the amount of the third or subsequent offence overpayment is recovered.
